reasoning: The critique targets a central pillar of the essay’s conditional optimism: that partial AM-convergence plus trade/compromise can still yield a mostly-great future. If moral trade robustly degenerates into extortion/commitment races, that substantially undercuts the compromise pathway (centrality ~0.7). However, much of this failure mode is already explicitly discussed in section 3.3 (threats, extortion, instability of threat-preventing institutions), so the critique is partly ‘priced in’ and functions more as an amplification than a new refutation. It adds a concrete game-theoretic story (credible commitment + disagreement-point manipulation) that could make threats structurally dominant, but it doesn’t demonstrate inevitability across plausible institutions (e.g., anti-commitment norms, enforcement constraints, bargaining protocols, coordination to punish threateners), so it weakens rather than refutes (strength ~0.35). The main claims are broadly plausible but somewhat overgeneral (e.g., equilibrium always rewards maximal destructiveness; ‘prevent renegotiation forever’), hence correctness ~0.7. It is clear, focused, and has little fluff.
title: Credible commitment mechanisms enable extortion and threat-based bargaining equilibria
